title: Specific heat - piece of metal in water

content.question: A <math alttext="0.050 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.050</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math> piece of an unknown metal is initially at a temperature of <math alttext="373 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>373</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>. The metal is then quickly moved into an insulated container with <math alttext="0.100 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math> of water at a temperature of <math alttext="295 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>295</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>. The water and the metal come to equilibrium at a temperature of <math alttext="300 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>. The specific heat of water is <math alttext="4184 joules per kilogram kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4184</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mtext>/</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>kg</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">·</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. What is the specific heat of the unknown metal?
